headline: Corporate America buckles down for culture war on Roe v Wade
author: Lauren Aratani
sentences: Jen Stark, senior director of corporate strategy at Tara Health Foundation, who helped coordinate the of over 180 executives in a statement against abortion bans in 2019, said the potential backlash from conservative lawmakers proves that companies need to act on abortion restrictions beyond mitigating effects for their employees.

But given the widespread impact the end of Roe v Wade will have on much of the country  will restrict abortion access if the decision is overturned  it is unlikely that companies can get away with not responding to the issue once the supreme court makes its final decision.

After a supreme court decision that overturns Roe v Wade was leaked and signaled the impending end of federal constitutional protection for abortions, a trickle of companies have slowly started to announce policies that provide abortion access for their employees.

Last month, Floridas governor, Ron DeSantis, special land use privileges the state gave to Disney for its Disney World theme park in Orlando after the company  responding to backlash from employees and consumers  spoke out against the states dont say gay? law.

When Citigroups CEO, Jane Fraser  the to lead a major American bank  was asked in a shareholders meeting about the companys new abortion travel benefit, she said the benefit isnt intended to be a statement about a very sensitive issue?.

A state lawmaker in Texas, infuriated by Citigroup, introduced a bill that would prevent companies from doing business with local governments in Texas if they provide abortion-related benefits to their employees.

Citigroup has now been joined by Amazon, Apple, Yelp, Match Group, Tesla and Levi Strauss & Company, all which have said they will offer travel assistance to employees who are in states that restrict abortions.
